text:
Being an adult
in a bouncy castle
is just unquestionably awesome,

Now you're making me
rethink my answer.
[jazzy music]

- Hi, folks,
Seth MacFarlane here,

and welcome to the Peacock
"At-Home Variety Show,"
benefiting great organizations

like Americares,
Feeding America,
and United Way,

all of whom are working very
hard to assist those in need
during this pandemic.

Well, here at
"The At-Home Variety Show,"

we are deeply committed
to entertaining you
for four and a half minutes,

and tonight, we have
a very special treat.
Ed Helms, Mike Schur,

and Sierra Teller Ornelas
are here.

They're gonna be
raising awareness

for the NDN Collective's
COVID-19 response project,
which provides immediate relief

to Native American nations
and frontline organizations,

many of whom have been
disproportionately affected
by the pandemic,
so folks, here they are--
Ed Helms, Mike Schur,
and Sierra Teller Ornelas.
- Hi, my name is Michael Schur.
- Hello, my name is Ed Helms.
- [speaking native language]

- Hi, my name is
Sierra Teller Ornelas.

I'm a member of
the Navajo Nation.

- Your introduction is way more
interesting
than mine and Ed's.
- A little bit.
- So Sierra and Ed and I

have been working
for a while now

on a new show
for the Peacock network
called "Rutherford Falls."
It will be out in 2021,

and we're very happy
to be part
of this Peacock fundraiser.

So, today we're gonna be
playing a game

that we play a lot
in the writers' room.

It's called,
Does Sierra Like It?
[bluegrass music]

And the reason that we play
this game

is that Sierra, the showrunner
of the show,

is an incredibly
passionate person.
She has a lot of conviction.

However--and this is the key
to the game--

there is literally no way
to predict
which direction she will go

in those convictions
about any topic.

So, we're gonna play this game
for you at home.

We're gonna throw out
some topics.

Sierra has not seen
these topics,

and so she's gonna be answering
truthfully

and honestly with all
of the conviction and passion

that she always answers
these questions with.

Ed, what is our
first category?

- Okay, does Sierra like
decorative paper napkins?
- This is a layup.
If I get this one wrong, I--
I mean, nothing will happen.
Ed, what did you say?

- Well, I admire
your confidence
that this is a layup.

There is no such thing
as a layup
in Does Sierra Like It?
You should know better.
I'm gonna say no.
- I said yes.

Sierra, do you like
decorative paper napkins?
- Not if they're paper.

That's so bad for
the environment.
You can't recycle them.

It's a nightmare.
It's a walking nightmare.
- Just to be clear,

decorative paper napkins
are a walking nightmare.
- Yeah.

Oh, okay, this is hard.
Ed, what do you got?
- Yeah, this is a tricky one.

Being an adult
in a bouncy castle
is just unquestionably awesome,
so I'm just gonna go with yes.

- [sighs] Now you're making me
rethink my answer.

But I--I said with no.
I'll go with no.

Sierra, do you like adults
in bouncy castles?

- I think that's the grossest
thing I could ever think of.
- Yes!

All right, does Sierra
like rollercoasters?

You said...
- I say no.

- Really?
I say yes.

Sierra, do you like
rollercoasters?

- Rollercoasters are the best.
They're the best thing ever.

I love the ones
that are dangerous--

the ones that you just, like,
build at a county fair,

and most of the fear
is coming from, like,

was this built properly?
- [scoffs]

- I don't think it's a good
rollercoaster

unless I yell, "Please, God,
don't let me die."

It's not really a rollercoaster
until you've done that.

- I'm gonna say Sierra does not
like scuba diving.

- I also said Sierra does not
like scuba diving.

Sierra, do you like
scuba diving?
- To walk among the fish? Yeah.

I like scuba diving.
Are you out of your mind?

- [scoffs]
- You're, like, deep down--
- To walk among the fish.

- I'm just saying,
and to do the things--

it's like going to space,
except you get to stay home

and you don't have to, like,
be really good
at being an astronaut.

Any mook can go into the ocean
and scuba dive.

[laughter]
- But that's not true.
- Have you done it before?

- There's, like,
extensive training.

- But I'm--yeah, you take--
have you met some scuba divers?
I'm just saying, I know--

I have a lot of uncles
that could scuba dive.

They couldn't go into space.
And it's awesome.
- Ed, what did you say?

Does Sierra like
the Spice Girls?
- I say yes.
- I--I also said yes.

Sierra, do you like
the Spice Girls?
- Hard no.
It's fake feminism.
One of them's called Baby.
It just--it doesn't age well.

- I thought I had that one.
I thought I had it nailed.
Next round.
Ed, what did you say?
- I say yes.
- I also said yes.

Sierra, do you like
breakfast for dinner?

- I think if you're making
breakfast for dinner,

you've completely given up
on your life, basically.
Breakfast is breakfast.

Breakfast is like--no,
pizza for breakfast, awesome.

Like, dinner for breakfast,
amazing.

- You know what?
The end result of this game

always is, you just are
dispirited.

You just lose your will
to continue.
Well, now you have it.

Ed, do you have any
final words?

- This was as fun
as it always is.
I love you guys.
[laughter]

- Sierra,
any final words?

- Thank you so much again,
and we hope that you guys
can donate to all the charities
that we're raising money for,
including NDN Collective--
that's NDN Collective--

and their COVID-19
reponse project.

It is designed to provide
immediate relief

to some of the most
underserved communities
in Indian country.

They have a specific fund
for the Navajo Nation,

but they are giving funds
to all Indian country

who really need it right now.
Thank you.
- Hi, everyone, I'm Mike Schur.

I was the co-creator
of "Parks and Recreation."
Earlier this month,

we put together a special
episode of the show

to raise money
for Feeding America's
COVID-19 relief fund.

We have a special donation link
that's still active

at
FeedingAmerica.org/parksandrec.

It was really wonderful to get
the whole cast back together.
And we also got to recreate one

of our favorite moments
from the show,

which was a tribute
to Li'l Sebastian,

the miniature horse who was
so important
to the town of Pawnee, Indiana.

It came from an episode,
you might remember,

in which Leslie Knope
charged Andy Dwyer

with writing a song
to memorialize Li'l Sebastian
after his death,
and she told him it had to be
"like 'Candles in the Wind'
but 5,000 times better."
Andy took that literally

and wrote a song called
"5,000 Candles in the Wind."

It's one of our
favorite moments,

one of our favorite episodes
of the show,

and we got to do another,
special version of it
all these years later,

so without further ado,
here is another look

at the entire cast
of "Parks and Rec"

singing "5,000 Candles
in the Wind."

- Leslie, you said you needed
something to lift your spirits,
so, Andrew?
Take it away.
[acoustic music]
- [gasps]

- ♪ Up in horsey heaven,
here's the thing ♪
- Every time with this song.

- Quiet!
- There we go.

- ♪ You trade your legs
for angels wings ♪

♪ Once we've all
said good-bye ♪

- This is a long song.
- Shup up, Ben!

- ♪ Take a running leap
and you learn to fly ♪

all: ♪ Bye-bye,
Li'l Sebastian ♪

♪ Miss you in
the saddest fashion ♪
♪ Bye-bye, Li'l Sebastian ♪

♪ You're 5,000 candles
in the wind ♪

- I--I'm gonna run out
my entire battery.
- [sighs]

- ♪ Though we all miss you
every day ♪

- ♪ We know you're up there
eating heaven's hay ♪

- ♪ And here's the part
that hurts the most ♪

- ♪ Humans cannot ride
a ghost ♪
- Everybody sing it now!

all: ♪ Bye-bye,
Li'l Sebastian ♪

♪ Miss you in
the saddest fashion ♪
♪ Bye-bye, Li'l Sebastian ♪

♪ You're 5,000 candles
in the wind ♪

- ♪ Maybe someday we'll
saddule up again ♪
♪ Know I'll always miss ♪
♪ My horsiest friend ♪

both: ♪ Spread your wings
and fly ♪
♪ Spread your wings and fly ♪
[all cheering]
- Oh, that was amazing!
[jazzy music]
